_chemical.ChemicalName: Vinyl acetate monomer  [Acetic acid ethenyl ester]

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
PURPOSE FOR RISK MANAGEMENT PLAN RESUBMISSION / UPDATE

Stolthaven Houston Inc. is updating the facility's Risk Management Plan (RMP) in March of 2010 to revise the operating scenario for a regulated toxic substance already present at the facility above the applicable threshold quantity in a newly covered process.  The specific changes associated with this RMP update include:

- Updating the RMP pursuant to the requirements of 40 CFR 68, Section A? 68.190(b)(4), due to Stolthaven Houston Inc. commencing the storage and associated parcel shipments of Toluene Diisocyanate (TDI) in the facility's D Tank Farm in existing Low-Pressure Storage Tank D-15-21 above the threshold quantity for TDI of 10,000-pounds.  

- Updating the RMP to reflect the consolidation of Vinyl Acetate Monomer (VAM) storage at Stolthaven Houston Inc. into IFR Storage Tank P-50-5 from prior, recent VAM storage in Tanks A-15-9, A-15-10, and P-15-41.

- Updating the Worst-Case Release scenarios for TDI storage in D Tank Farm and for VAM storage in P Tank Farm using maximum historical temperature data for the affected tanks.

- Minor RMP data element updates based on October 2009 revisions to the facility's Safety and Health Manual.  


A?68.155(a):  ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES

At Stolthaven Houston Inc. we are committed to operating and maintaining all of our processes related to bulk chemical storage and distribution in a safe and responsible manner.  We use a combination of accidental release prevention and emergency response planning programs to protect the environment and to ensure the safety of our employees as well as the citizens of the surrounding communities.  This document provides a brief overview of the comprehensive risk management activities that Stolthaven Houston Inc. has designed and implemented, including:

- A description of our facility and the substances regulated by 40 CFR Part 68 that are currently handled on-site above their corresponding thr

eshold quantities
- An overview of our accidental release prevention programs
- A five-year accident history for significant accidental releases from processes covered by EPA's RMP rule
- An overview of our emergency response programs
- An overview of improvements at the facility implemented to help prevent accidental chemical releases from occurring and adversely affecting our employees, the public, the environment, and company assets
- Detailed information (i.e. data elements) about our Risk Management Program


A?68.155(b):  STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED

Stolthaven Houston Inc. owns and operates an existing bulk liquids storage and distribution terminal located on the north side of the Houston Ship Channel near Channelview in eastern Harris County, Texas.  The facility currently consists of 148 large above-ground chemical storage tanks, four truck loading/unloading racks (T-3, T-4, T-5, and T-6), three rail car loading/unloading racks (R-1, R-2, and R-3), one barge dock (Barge Dock C), and a finger pier equipped with two separate marine vessel berths (Ship Dock 2/3).  A waste water treatment plant and various air pollution control devices are also located on-site.  Bulk liquid products are received into the Stolthaven Houston Terminal by various modes of transportation cargo containers that can include tank trucks, ISO tank containers, rail tank cars, barges, and/or marine parcel tankers (ships).  The received liquid products are stored on-site according to customer-specified requirements, and are subsequently transferred off-site through one or more of the above-referenced transportation modes.  Stolthaven Houston Inc. also performs direct transfers between marine vessels and rail tanks cars with no intermediate product storage.  Similarly, land-based intermodal transfers directly between tank trucks, ISO tank containers, and rail tank cars are also performed routinely at the Stolthaven Houston Terminal.  Note that Stolthaven Houston Inc. d

oes not perform any chemical processing or chemical manufacturing operations on-site, and the company does not own nor ultimately control any of the bulk liquid products that are stored or otherwise handled at the facility.

The following chemicals presently handled at Stolthaven Houston Inc. have been identified by the EPA as having the potential to cause significant off-site consequences in the event of a substantial accidental release:

Regulated Toxic Substances (2):

Toluene Diisocyanate (CAS Number 26471-62-5) &
Vinyl Acetate Monomer (CAS Number 108-05-4)

Regulated Flammable Substances (2):

Normal Pentane (CAS Number 109-66-0),
Isopentane (CAS Number 78-78-4), &
Normal Pentane (> 45%) / Isopentane (< 55%) Blends

TDI and VAM currently represent the only two RMP regulated substances at Stolthaven Houston Inc. that are present above their corresponding threshold quantities at all times.  Pentane, Isopentane, and Pentane Blends are periodically transloaded between land-based transportation containers with no intermediate on-site product storage.  As a result, the above-referenced Pentanes are not always present on-site at the Stolthaven Houston Terminal.  

Our training and accidental release prevention programs in combination with our Standard Operating Procedures (SOP) and contingency planning efforts help us effectively manage the potential hazards posed to our employees, the public, and the environment through the storage and/or transfer of the above-referenced RMP regulated chemicals.

Stolthaven Houston Inc. currently stores Toluene Diisocyanate (TDI) in one 15,000-barrel nominal capacity above-ground storage tank:  Low-Pressure Storage Tank D-15-22.  This tank has a fill-restricted maximum TDI storage capacity of 525,369-gallons, or approximately 5,348,256-pounds of TDI.  Periodic direct transfers of TDI from marine vessels to rail tank cars is also performed at Stolthaven Houston Inc. with no intermediate product storage.  Note that Stolthaven Houston I

nc. currently has over 15-years of experience in the storage and handling of TDI.

In late March of 2010 Stolthaven Houston Inc. proposes to commence the storage of TDI in a second 15,000-barrel capacity above-ground storage tank at the facility:  Low-Pressure Storage Tank D-15-21.  Tank D-15-21 is an existing low-pressure tank that is located adjacent to Stolthaven Houston's existing TDI Storage Tank D-15-22.  Tank D-15-21 has a fill-restricted maximum TDI working capacity of 615,672-gallons, or approximately 6,267,541-pounds of TDI.  Note that Tank D-15-21 has been recently modified specifically to handle TDI, including the installation of an activated carbon drum on the Tank D-15-21 flare vapor line, and connecting the existing TDI rail transfer line and the existing TDI marine dock line to Tank D-15-21 to minimize and eliminate connections that must be made for equipment in active TDI service.  

Isopentane, n-Pentane, and iso/normal pentane blends are periodically transloaded directly between land-based transportation containers (i.e. tank trucks, ISO tank containers, and rail tank cars) at the Stolthaven Houston Terminal with no intermediate product storage.  

On April 13, 2009 Stolthaven Houston Inc. commenced the storage and associated transfers of Vinyl Acetate Monomer (VAM), a RMP regulated toxic substance, in quantities greater than 15,000-pounds in either of two existing 15,000-barrel capacity IFR storage tanks located in the terminal's A Tank Farm (Tanks A-15-9 and A-15-10).  On January 28, 2010 Stolthaven Houston Inc. temporarily consolidated the terminal's existing A Tank Farm VAM storage into Tank P-15-41.  Temporary VAM storage in Tank P-15-41 was necessary until enough VAM product became available to place the current VAM tank, Storage Tank P-50-5, into long-term service with an adequate volume of liquid product to maintain this tank's internal floating roof on-float as required by NSPS Subpart Kb.

Storage Tank P-50-5 is an existing IFR tank at t

he Stolthaven Houston Terminal with a maximum working capacity of approximately 50,142-barrels, which corresponds to a maximum VAM storage capacity of just under 16,365,000-pounds.  Tank P-50-5, which represents the facility's worst-case VAM release scenario, was subsequently placed into VAM service for the first time on February 25, 2010.  VAM is received into this tank via barge delivery using a dedicated marine dock line.  Product is then shipped outbound according to customer requirements via marine parcel tankers that load at Stolthaven Houston's existing Ship Dock 2/3.  VAM may also be transferred periodically directly from barges to rail tank cars with no intermediate storage.

As a result of the VAM storage project in P Tank Farm, piping modifications were completed in various facility manifolds and at Tank P-50-5 to eliminate the use of hoses in VAM service to the greatest extent possible within the terminal.  A VAM filter-pot was also installed.  Stolthaven Houston's permanent, stationary fire-water protection systems in the immediate area of Tank P-50-5 were also upgraded to provide additional cooling water as-needed in the event of an emergency incident involving any of the the facility's flammable liquid storage tanks in close proximity.  Existing portable water delivery systems also remain available should they be needed in the event of an emergency.

Employee training related to the specifics of VAM storage and transfer at the Stolthaven Houston Terminal was first conducted in December of 2008 and then again in April of 2009 in preparation of receiving this RMP regulated substance into the facility's A Tank Farm in 2009.  Although current facility employees are experienced in the procedures necessary to safely handle VAM, additional safety training related specifically to VAM storage in P Tank Farm was conducted in December of 2009.  Specific topics covered during this employee review of safe VAM handling procedures included, but were not limited to,

the following information:  product transfer modes and affected facility equipment, VAM technical and physical properties, inhibitor specifications and periodic verification, nitrogen blanketing to maintain low oxygen levels, special product hazards and warnings, required personal protective equipment (PPE), and environmental/regulatory considerations.  VAM has been successfully handled at Stolthaven Houston Inc. since April of 2009 without significant incident.  

Note that Storage Tanks A-15-9, A-15-10, and P-15-41 at Stolthaven Houston Inc. were all removed from VAM service before being gas-freed and cleaned during the first quarter of 2010.  These three tanks will be prepared for the storage of different substances that are not currently covered under the 40 CFR 68 regulations.  As such, Storage Tanks A-15-9, A-15-10, and P-15-41 are no longer covered processes under the RMP rules.

   
A?68.155(c):  ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

We take a systematic, proactive approach to preventing accidental releases of hazardous chemicals.  Our management systems address each of the key features of successful prevention programs, including:

- Process Safety Information (PSI)
- Process Hazard Analysis (PHA)
- ISO 9001: 2000 Certified Quality Management System (QMS)
- Employee Training / Local Training Manual (LTM)
- Mechanical Integrity Program
- Spill Containment
- Management of Change (MOC)
- Pre-Startup Safety Review (PSSR)
- Vapor Control Systems
- Compliance Audits
- Formal Incident Investigation
- Employee Participation Program
- Hot Work / Safe Work Permits
- Departmental / Safety Meetings
- Facility Safety Committee
- Emergency Response Team (ERT)
- Emergency / Incident Response Contractors

The above-referenced elements of our prevention program work together to help prevent accidental chemical releases.  Our company and our employees are committed to the standard that these management systems set for the way we conduc

t business, and we have specific accountabilities and controls in place to ensure that we meet our own high standards for accident prevention.


A?68.155(d):  FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

During the preceding five (5) years there have been no accidental releases from RMP covered processes at the Stolthaven Houston Terminal which resulted in death, injuries, or significant property damage on-site.  Similarly, there have been no accidental releases from any RMP covered processes which resulted in known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage.

All incidents and non-routine product releases at the Stolthaven Houston Terminal are formally investigated as part of our facility's ISO Quality Management System (QMS) to identify and correct the root cause(s) of any events, and to implement appropriate corrective actions for continuous process improvement.


A?68.155(e):  EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

We maintain an integrated contingency plan, which consolidates the various federal, state, and local regulatory requirements for emergency response planning.  Our emergency response program provides the essential planning and training for effectively protecting our employees, the public, the environment, and company assets during potential emergency situations.  Furthermore, we coordinate our action plan with the community emergency response plan and the North Channel Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC).

An Emergency Action Plan (EAP) is maintained which provides guidelines for responding to various emergencies such as fires, hazardous material spills, personal injuries, severe weather events, and property damage that may occur at the Stolthaven Houston Terminal.  


A?68.155(f):  PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

The following is a list of procedures implemented at the Stolthaven Houston Terminal to prevent and/or better respond to accidental chemical releases:

- PHA and adaptation of PHA recommendations
- Conti

nuous improvement through the facility's ISO 9001: 2000 Certified Quality Management System (QMS)
- Employee Suggestion / Experience Feedback Program
- Regular safety meetings with Stolthaven Houston operations employees and contract personnel working in the Stolthaven Houston Terminal
- Facility Safety Committee

As a result of the most recent complete facility PHA conducted in October of 2009, capital expense upgrades to the Stolthaven Houston Terminal's fire water delivery system were budgeted for the 2010 fiscal year.  As a result, new fire water delivery monitors were recently installed to improve coverage for flammable liquids stored in P Tank Farm.  Additional modifications to the D Tank Farm fire-fighting water delivery systems are planned for later in 2010, with completion expected on approximately September 1, 2010.
